Ah stay! — thy wand oblivious o'er my eyes</br>Yet wave, mild power of sleep! — my pray'r is vain;</br>She flies, the partial nurse of nature flies,</br>With all her soothing visionary train.

Then let me forth; and near yon flowering thorn</br>Taste heav'n's pure breath; while rob'd in amber vest,</br>Fresh from her watry couch, the youthful morn</br>Steals on the slumbers of the drowzy east.

Lo, at her presence, the strong arm of toil,</br>With glittering sickle, mows the prime of may;</br>While yon poor hirelings, for the mine's rude soil,</br>Leave to their sleeping babes their cots of clay.
With sturdy step, they cheerly whistle o'er</br>The path that flings across the reedy plain,</br>To the deep caverns of that yawning moor,</br>Whose shaggy breast abhors the golden grain.
There, in her green dress, nature never roves,</br>Spreads the gay lawn, nor lifts the lordly pine,</br>They see no melting clouds refresh the groves,</br>No living landscape drawn by hands divine.
But many a fathom from the sunny breeze,</br>Their painful way in central night they wear;</br>Heave the pik'd axes on their bended knees,</br>Or sidelong the rough quarry slowly tear.
Yet while damp vapours chill each reeking brow,</br>How loudly laughs the jovial voice of mirth;</br>Pleas'd that the wages of the day allow</br>A social blaze to cheer their ev'ning hearth.
There the chaste housewife, with maternal care,</br>Her thirsty distaf plies, in grave attire;</br>Blest to behold her ruddy offspring wear</br>The full resemblance of their sturdy sire,
To spread with such coarse fare their homely board</br>As fits the genius of their little fate,</br>Free from those ills that haunt their pamper'd lord;</br>To be unhappy we must first be great.

In these dark caves, where heav'n's paternal hand,</br>Far from the world, their private cradle laid,</br>They toil secure:  the storms that strike the land</br>With wild dismay, roll harmless o'er their head.
For who, the load of weary life to bear,</br>Wou'd from these murky mansions chace the slave?</br>Who cease to breathe heav'n's pure and chearful air,</br>To be but living tenants of the grave?

Yet harras'd as they are, their face still wears</br>The reverend comeliness of green old age;</br>No stains their mind from worldly science bears;</br>Their ray of knowledge gleams from nature's page.

The few plain rules her simple lessons give,</br>They still thro' life with pleas'd attention ply;</br>Their helpless offspring bid them wish to live,</br>Their breathless parents bid them learn to die.
And surely heav'n, whose penetrating sight</br>Pierces the soul, and reads its inmost groan,</br>Must see content, with more sincere delight,</br>Toil in the mine, than triumph on the throne;

See Charles, more pleas'd, within the convent's gloom,</br>Seeking the slaves calm nights, their temperate days,</br>And peaceful passage to the private tomb,</br>Than diadem'd with glory's crimson rays.
Ev'n the proud sage, whose deep mysterious brain</br>Has reason'd all the balm of hope away,</br>Convinc'd that  learning's but ingenious pain,</br>Might hail their happier lot, and sighing say,
"Oh had I thus, within the dark profound,</br>By daily labor earn'd my daily food;</br>Or with yon seedsman sow'd the quickening ground,</br>Or cleav'd with ponderous ax the groaning wood!
"Full many an hour that now, tho' sped with art,</br>On slow and dusky pinions sullen flies,</br>Full many an anxious wish, or pang of heart,</br>That reason's boasted anodyne defies,
"Had ne'er been born.  Nor had th' uneasy mind,</br>Pent in the prison of this mortal mould,</br>Felt its ethereal energy confin'd,</br>Its brightest sunshine in dark clouds enroll'd.
"But native sense her modest course had run;</br>Her saintly lustre untaught virtue spread;</br>Health crown'd my toils, and ere the day was done,</br>Sound sleep beneath some alder's rustling shade.

"Then, as I stole down life's declining hill,</br>Here nature's gifts had furnish'd nature's needs,</br>The brook's cold beverage ev'ry latent ill</br>Had starv'd, that cloyster'd contemplation feeds.

"Till, in the peaceful shade of this lone bower,</br>Or near yon shattered tower in silence laid,</br>The orient orb, that watch'd my natal hour,</br>Had brightly glitter'd o'er my mouldering head."</br>
